div1.p:

FROM DR. HOWARD KELLY
Reed Birthplace As Shrine
Baltimore Sun, January 9, 1927.

Move Afoot
To Buy Small
Virginia House
Where Yellow
Fever Hero
Was A Baby
By ALLYN B. TUNIS.

BACK a little way from the cross-
roads at Belroi, a modest postoffice
in Gloucester county, Virginia, not far
from the York river, is a tiny weather-
beaten building. It is without paint,
minus doors and shows every mark of
dilapidated abandonment.

It has been there for nearly one hun-
dred years, undistinguished by any
mark to call attention to the fact that
here was born the man who wiped out
yellow fever and showed public health
surgeons how to control typhoid and
other deadly epidemic diseases.

Without the discoveries of Walter
Reed, it would have been impossible to
build the Panama Canal; otherwise the
Canal Zone would not have been habit-
able for the Americans who created that
important waterway.
HOSPITAL BEARS NAME.

America did not completely recognize
Walter Reed at first. After his death
the Walter Reed Hospital, at Washing-
ton, was erected as a memorial to him.
In Newport News, Va., a public school
bears his name and contains this tab-
let: “To the Memory of Walter C.
Reed, Major, Medical Corps, U. S.
Army. Born Gloucester County, Vir-
ginia, 1846. Died Washington, D. C.,
1902. Scientist, Humanitarian and
Discoverer of the Cause and Prevention
of Serious Epidemic Diseases.”

For years the little house in Virginia
has been unrecognized. There has been
a widespread opinion that Walter Reed
was born at Harrisonburg, Rockingham

The birthplace of Walter Reed, at Belroi, Va., which may be
made into a national shrine if present plans are carried out.

county, Va. This error probably was
due to the fact that Walter Reed's
father, who was a Methodist minister,
moved his family from Gloucester to
Harrisonburg to take another pastorate,
although Dr. John C. Reed, a brother,
asserts that Walter Reed never lived in
Harrisonburg.

Apparently there is no doubt of the
authenticity of the house at Belroi being
Walter Reed's birthplace. Eighty years
after his birth, the shabby house is about
to be repaired and preserved as a na-
tional shrine.
DEFINITE ACTION TAKEN.

There have been movements from
time to time and by various organiza-
tions to take over the property, but only
last month, when the danger of the
frail building falling into irreparable
decay was detected, was definite action
taken.

It was decided by the Medical Society
of Virginia, through a committee headed
by Dr. Clarence Porter Jones, of New-
port News, to take over the property
and protect it against obliteration and
possible destruction by fire. It was
owned by the storekeeper and post-
master at Belroi, George D. Stubbs, who
executed a deed conveying the house
and less than an acre of land on which
it stands to the society.
WAS PLANTATION THEN.

A movement now is on foot to induce
the State Board of Education to per-
mit Virginia school children to give to
a fund which will be used to convert
the property into a national memorial.

Before the Civil War Beroi was not a
village and had not reached the im-
portance of being a postoffice. It was a
plantation, called Belle-Roy, named in
honor of its mistress and master.

Across the road from the manor house
stood the Gloucester county Methodist
parsonage. When the Rev. Mr. Reed
and his family came to this charge his
family temporarily was domiciled in the
overseer's house at Belle-Roy, the par-
sonage undergoing repairs at the time.
The overseer's house boatsed only a
story and a half. The one-room section
was added about forty years ago.

In 1898, when the Spanish-American
War broke out, Captain Reed was ap-
pointed head of a board to study typhoid
fever epidemics, which fast were killing
American soldiers in Southern camps.

Captain Reed was selected to lead a
board in Cuba to study yellow fever.
For years ravages of this disease had
been severe on the island. There had
been outbreaks in many parts of the
United States; epidemics in the South.
It was regarded as a constant menace in
the South. Prevention and remedies
were unknown.
PROVED HIS CASE.

To support Captain Reed's theory
about yellow fever, it was necessary
that men volunteer to submit themselves
to mosquito bites. Experiments es-
tablished the fact that yellow fever is
transmitted by mosquitoes.

Dr. Reed proved that the mosquito is
the only means of transmitting the
dread disease.

Dr. Reed was recognized as one of
the world's greatest discoverers in the
field of preventive medicine, although
he did not live to reap the full measure
of the honors heaped upon his name at
home and abroad.

At his birthplace the little piece of
ground will be made into a park and
the spot easily can be reached by motor-
ists, as it is just a few miles off the
Tidewater Virginia Trail.

The Medical Society of Virginia is at
work on plans to raise $100,000 to es-
tablish a Walter Reed memorial chair
of medical research at the University of
Virginia.
